intro: Sisyrinchium marchio, commonly known as the March grass-vetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, seed-like fruits that are dispersed by wind. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
